Yes, the Manchu dynasty faced several significant rebellions and uprisings during its rule. Some of the most notable ones include:

1. The Three Feudatories Rebellion: This rebellion occurred in the early 1670s and was led by three powerful military governors who were dissatisfied with the central government's control over their territories. The Qing dynasty was able to crush the rebellion, but only after several years of fighting.

2. The Taiping Rebellion: This was one of the largest and most destructive rebellions in Chinese history. It was led by a man named Hong Xiuquan, who believed he was the younger brother of Jesus Christ. The rebellion lasted from 1850 to 1864 and resulted in the deaths of an estimated 20 million people.

3. The Boxer Rebellion: This was a popular uprising that took place in 1900 and was led by a secret society called the Boxers. The Boxers were opposed to foreign influence in China and targeted foreigners and Chinese Christians for violence. The rebellion was ultimately suppressed by a joint military force of foreign powers.

These rebellions and uprisings highlight the challenges that the Manchu dynasty faced in maintaining control over China, particularly in the face of widespread discontent and opposition.
